content: The Department of Defense (DOD) fuel consumption fluctuates annually based on mission needs. DOD may use up to 1% of US refined petroleum products, with foreign purchases potentially doubling consumption. The Defense Energy Support Center (DESC) procures fuel for all DOD services and agencies, both in the US and overseas. DESC's origins trace back to World War II, evolving into the Defense Logistics Agency (DLA) and later the Defense Energy Support Center in 1998 with an expanded energy management mission. In 1964, the Defense Energy Support Center (DESC) was established to manage DOD's petroleum products and coal purchases. In 1998, DESC's mission expanded to include managing a variety of energy products. DESC awards fuel contracts based on cost and manages bulk petroleum products, bunker fuel, refueling at airports, and post-camp-and-station fuel. DOD primarily consumes JP-8, JP-5, and diesel fuel. This report analyzes DOD's fuel purchases from FY2000 to FY2008, comparing spending to overall DOD expenses, fuel prices to commercial rates, and quantities purchased to U.S. refined petroleum production. The report compares DOD's fuel purchases to U.S. refined petroleum production, discusses refining and refineries supplying DOD's jet fuel, and recent legislation promoting alternative fuels. Legislation now focuses on not exacerbating global warming with new fuel sources. Legislation now prohibits federal agencies from funding new fuel sources that worsen global warming. Proposed rules on greenhouse gas reporting may have minimal impact on refineries. New legislation to cap greenhouse gas emissions could affect refinery operations and responsiveness to DOD's fuel needs. DESC's bulk fuel purchases mainly consist of JP-8 jet fuel, with the Air Force and Army as primary consumers. DESC's total fuel purchases peaked in FY2003 during the Iraq invasion, with JP-8 purchases peaking in FY2004 and declining since then. DESC's fuel purchases peaked at 145.1 million barrels in FY2003 during the Iraq invasion. JP-8 purchases peaked in FY2004 and have been declining since. Overall DESC fuel expenditures grew from $3.6 billion in FY2000 to nearly $18 billion in FY2008, a 500% increase. Actual volumes purchased only increased by 30% over the same time period. Fuel costs and average prices continued to rise due to increasing crude oil prices and refining margins. The cost of petroleum products purchased rose significantly from FY2000 to FY2008, driven by increasing crude oil prices and refining margins. Jet fuel prices reversed their price advantage over commercial aviation fuel, leading to increased purchases of alternate jet fuels. The margin between refiners' crude oil cost and refined product prices also increased during this period. From FY2000 to FY2008, defense outlays increased by 200%, with Operation and Maintenance spending rising by 231%. Fuel costs surged by 497%, reaching 3% of DOD's spending by FY2008. The Interior Department generates revenue from Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) leases, with royalties-in-kind paid by OCS lessees in the form of oil delivered to the Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR). The SPR was created in response to the 1970s Arab oil embargo to prevent supply disruptions, holding roughly 70 days of imported supply when filled to capacity. Drawdowns from the SPR can involve sales to the highest bidder or exchanges. In 1991, President George H.W. Refineries processing heavy oil cannot operate at normal capacity with lighter oils, affecting 36 vulnerable refineries. If these refineries had to use SPR oil, U.S. refining throughput could decrease by 735,000 barrels per day. The SPR's effectiveness during an oil disruption, especially with heavy oil, would be significantly reduced.
